This leads me to propose a quicker method through recursion or building blocks based approach like below which reuses previous computations efficiently.Let's denote our base case as follows:

Multiplying matrix $\mathbf{A}$ by itself yields \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} (3)(3)+(7)(-1) & (3)(7)+(7)(-2) \\ (-1)(3)+(-2)(-1) & (-1)(7)+(-2)(-2) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.\] The answer is $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
